data.name: AssignedByValParameterInspectionMeta
data.value: Parameter is passed by value, but is assigned a new value/reference. Consider making a local copy instead.

data.name: AssignedByValParameterInspectionName
data.value: ByVal parameter is assigned

data.name: CodeQualityIssues
data.value: Code quality issues

data.name: ConstantNotUsedInspectionMeta
data.value: Constant value is declared but Rubberduck could not find any reference to it. Consider removing the unused declaration.

data.name: ConstantNotUsedInspectionName
data.value: Constant is not referred to

data.name: DefaultProjectNameInspectionMeta
data.value: Consider naming your VBA project.

data.name: DefaultProjectNameInspectionName
data.value: Project has default project name

data.name: EmptyStringLiteralInspection
data.value: Prefer 'vbNullString' to an empty string literal

data.name: EmptyStringLiteralInspectionMeta
data.value: The built-in constant 'vbNullString' is a null string pointer taking up 0 bytes of memory, that unambiguously conveys the intent of an empty string.

data.name: EmptyStringLiteralInspectionName
data.value: Empty string literal

data.name: EmptyStringLiteralInspectionQuickFix
data.value: Replace empty string with the 'vbNullString' constant

data.name: EncapsulatePublicFieldInspection
data.value: Make field '{0}' a property

data.name: EncapsulatePublicFieldInspectionMeta
data.value: Use properties rather than public fields.

data.name: EncapsulatePublicFieldInspectionName
data.value: Use properties rather than public fields.

data.name: EncapsulatePublicFieldInspectionQuickFix
data.value: Encapsulate field '{0}' with property

data.name: IgnoreOnce
data.value: Ignore once

data.name: ImplicitActiveSheetReferenceInspectionMeta
data.value: Implicit references to the active sheet make the code frail and harder to debug. Consider making these references explicit when they're intended, and prefer working off object references.

data.name: ImplicitActiveSheetReferenceInspectionName
data.value: Implicit reference to ActiveSheet

data.name: ImplicitActiveWorkbookReferenceInspectionMeta
data.value: Implicit references to the active workbook make the code frail and harder to debug. Consider making these references explicit when they're intended, and prefer working off object references.

data.name: ImplicitActiveWorkbookReferenceInspectionName
data.value: Implicit reference to ActiveWorkbook

data.name: ImplicitByRefParameterInspectionMeta
data.value: Parameters are passed by reference unless specified otherwise, which can be confusing and bug-prone. Prefer passing parameters by value, and specify ByRef explicitly when passing parameters by reference.

data.name: ImplicitByRefParameterInspectionName
data.value: Implicit ByRef parameter

data.name: ImplicitPublicMemberInspectionMeta
data.value: Module members are public by default, which can be counter-intuitive. Consider specifying explicit access modifiers to avoid ambiguity.

data.name: ImplicitPublicMemberInspectionName
data.value: Implicitly public member

data.name: ImplicitVariantReturnTypeInspectionMeta
data.value: Members with a return value implicitly return a 'Variant' unless specified otherwise. Consider returning an explicit 'Variant' when the return type isn't known, or specify it explicitly.

data.name: ImplicitVariantReturnTypeInspectionName
data.value: Return type is implicitly 'Variant'

data.name: MoveFieldCloseToUsageInspection
data.value: Move field closer to usage

data.name: MoveFieldCloseToUsageInspectionMeta
data.value: A field that is only used in one method should be a local variable.

data.name: MoveFieldCloseToUsageInspectionName
data.value: Move field closer to usage

data.name: MoveFieldCloseToUsageInspectionQuickFix
data.value: Move field '{0}' closer to usage

data.name: LanguageOpportunities
data.value: Language opportunities

data.name: MaintainabilityAndReadabilityIssues
data.value: Maintainability & readability issues

data.name: MultilineParameterInspectionMeta
data.value: Consider continuing long signatures between parameters. Splitting a parameter declaration across multiple lines arguably hurts readability.

data.name: MultilineParameterInspectionName
data.value: Parameter declaration is split on multiple lines

data.name: MultipleDeclarationsInspectionMeta
data.value: Declaring multiple variables in the same instruction is legal, but should be used sparingly. Consider declaring variables closer to their usage, in a single instruction per declaration.

data.name: MultipleDeclarationsInspectionName
data.value: Instruction contains multiple declarations

data.name: MultipleFolderAnnotationsInspection
data.value: '{0}' has more than one '@Folder' annotation.

data.name: MultipleFolderAnnotationsInspectionMeta
data.value: Rubberduck only uses the first '@Folder' annotation in a code module; consider removing extraneous ones.

data.name: MultipleFolderAnnotationsInspectionName
data.value: '{0}' has more than one folder annotation.

data.name: NonReturningFunctionInspectionMeta
data.value: This is likely a bug. The return value of a function or property getter must be assigned before exiting, otherwise the program will not be working with expected results. If a function has no meaningful return value, consider declaring it as a 'Sub' procedure instead.

data.name: NonReturningFunctionInspectionName
data.value: Non-returning function or property getter

data.name: ObsoleteCallStatementInspectionMeta
data.value: The 'Call' statement is no longer required to call procedures, and only exists in the language to support legacy code that required it; it can be safely rewritten to an implicit call.

data.name: ObsoleteCallStatementInspectionName
data.value: 'Call' statement usage

data.name: ObsoleteCommentSyntaxInspectionMeta
data.value: The 'Rem' statement only exists in the language to support legacy code that required it; it can be safely replaced with an apostrophe / single-quote comment.

data.name: ObsoleteCommentSyntaxInspectionName
data.value: 'Rem' statement usage

data.name: ObsoleteGlobalInspectionMeta
data.value: The 'Global' keyword only exists in the language to support legacy code that required it; it can be safely replaced with the 'Public' modifier.

data.name: ObsoleteGlobalInspectionName
data.value: 'Global' statement usage

data.name: ObsoleteLetStatementInspectionMeta
data.value: The 'Let' statement only exists in the language to support legacy code that required it; it can be safely removed, since modern VBA does not require that keyword for value assignments.

data.name: ObsoleteLetStatementInspectionName
data.value: 'Let' statement usage

data.name: ObsoleteTypeHintInspectionMeta
data.value: Type hint characters only exist in the language to support legacy code that required it; they can be safely replaced in declarations with an "As" type clause that specifies the type explicitly, and they can be omitted in other identifier references.

data.name: ObsoleteTypeHintInspectionName
data.value: Type hint usage

data.name: OptionBaseInspectionMeta
data.value: Arrays are typically zero-based. This option changes the default lower boundary for implicitly-sized arrays, which can introduce off-by-one errors if one isn't cautious.

data.name: OptionBaseInspectionName
data.value: 'Option Base 1' is specified

data.name: OptionExplicitInspectionMeta
data.value: Rubberduck works best when all used identifiers are declared. Allowing the usage of undeclared variables can cause easily avoidable bugs. Always specify Option Explicit.

data.name: OptionExplicitInspectionName
data.value: 'Option Explicit' is not specified

data.name: ParameterCanBeByValInspectionMeta
data.value: A parameter that is passed by reference and isn't assigned a new value/reference, could be passed by value instead.

data.name: ParameterCanBeByValInspectionName
data.value: Parameter can be passed by value

data.name: ParameterNotUsedInspectionMeta
data.value: A parameter is passed into a member that does not use it. Consider removing that parameter.

data.name: ParameterNotUsedInspectionName
data.value: Parameter is not referred to

data.name: ProcedureNotUsedInspectionMeta
data.value: Rubberduck could not find any caller for a procedure. If the procedure is hooked to a macro-button, used as a user-defined function (UDF) or handles an application event that Rubberduck didn't know of you can safely ignore this inspection result; otherwise, consider removing it.

data.name: ProcedureNotUsedInspectionName
data.value: Procedure is not referred to

data.name: UnassignedVariableUsageInspectionMeta
data.value: This is likely a bug. A variable is being referred to, but is never assigned.

data.name: UnassignedVariableUsageInspectionName
data.value: Variable is used but not assigned

data.name: UntypedFunctionUsageInspectionMeta
data.value: A string-returning equivalent function exists and should preferably be used to avoid implicit type conversions.

data.name: UntypedFunctionUsageInspectionName
data.value: Use of variant-returning string function

data.name: ProcedureShouldBeFunctionInspection
data.value: Procedure '{0}' can be written as a function.

data.name: ProcedureShouldBeFunctionInspectionQuickFix
data.value: Implement as function and update usages.

data.name: UseMeaningfulNameInspection
data.value: Consider renaming {0} '{1}'

data.name: UseMeaningfulNameInspectionMeta
data.value: Identifier names should indicate what they're used for and should be readable; avoid disemvoweling, numeric suffixes, and 1-2 character names.

data.name: UseMeaningfulNameInspectionName
data.value: Use meaningful names

data.name: VariableNotAssignedInspectionMeta
data.value: A variable is declared, but never assigned a value/reference. If Rubberduck is correct, the variable could probably be safely removed.

data.name: VariableNotAssignedInspectionName
data.value: Unassigned variable

data.name: VariableNotUsedInspectionMeta
data.value: A variable is declared and assigned a value/reference, but it's never referred to.

data.name: VariableNotUsedInspectionName
data.value: Variable is not referred to

data.name: VariableTypeNotDeclaredInspectionMeta
data.value: A variable whose type isn't explicitly declared, is implicitly 'Variant'. Consider making it an explicit 'Variant' if that's intended, or declare a more specific type.

data.name: VariableTypeNotDeclaredInspectionName
data.value: Variable is implicitly 'Variant'

data.name: WriteOnlyPropertyInspectionMeta
data.value: A property that exposes a mutator but no accessor is a design smell and makes a confusing API. Consider exposing a getter, or converting the mutator to a method.

data.name: WriteOnlyPropertyInspectionName
data.value: Write-only property

data.name: ProcedureShouldBeFunctionInspectionMeta
data.value: A procedure that only has one parameter passed by reference that is assigned a new value/reference before the procedure exits, is using a ByRef parameter as a return value: consider making it a function instead.

data.name: ProcedureShouldBeFunctionInspectionName
data.value: Procedure can be written as a function

data.name: WriteOnlyPropertyInspection
data.value: Property '{0}' has no getter

data.name: SelfAssignedDeclarationInspection
data.value: Declaration '{0}' is self-assigned

data.name: SelfAssignedDeclarationInspectionMeta
data.value: A declaration should not be self-assigned.

data.name: SelfAssignedDeclarationInspectionName
data.value: Self-assigned property

data.name: AssignmentValueNeverUsedInspection
data.value: Value assigned to '{0}' is never used

data.name: AssignmentValueNeverUsedInspectionMeta
data.value: Value is re-assigned before assigned value is used

data.name: AssignmentValueNeverUsedInspectionName
data.value: Remove unused assignment

data.name: AssignmentValueNeverUsedInspectionQuickFix
data.value: Remove unused assignment to '{0}'
